questions.text: A neurologist is assessing a teenage girl who has been experiencing fatigue severe enough to prevent her participation in physical education classes. She presents with muscle weakness in her limbs. Lab tests indicate high serum levels of triacylglycerols esterified with long-chain fatty acids (LCFAs) and hypoglycemia. A muscle biopsy shows an abundance of lipid vacuoles. What condition do these clinical findings suggest?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carnitine deficiency

 

Option A:

 

  • Carnitine deficiency is seen in preterm infants, where impaired fatty acid oxidation is noticed → so more glucose is utilized → episodes of hypoglycemia.
  • Primary carnitine deficiency: Classical presentation is hypoketotic hypoglycemic encephalopathy, hepatomegaly, elevated transaminases and ammonia, cardiomyopathy, pericardial effusion, muscle weakness, recurrent episodes of vomiting and diarrhea and infections and hypochromic anemia.
  • The above symptoms are triggered by fasting or viral infections.
  • Secondary carnitine deficiency: c/f-Hypoketotic hypoglycemia in infancy, cardiac and skeletal muscle disease later in life, seizures, apnea and developmental delay.
  • The causes for secondary carnitine deficiency includes organic acidurias, respiratory chain and mitochondrial defects, renal Fanconi syndrome and drug induced (valproic acid, zidovudine).

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Affects the de novo synthesis of fatty acids occurs in the cytoplasm with the help of a dimeric multi-enzyme complex termed Fatty acid synthase.

 

Option C: Deficiency of hexosaminidase A leads to accumulation of Ganglioside (GM2). C/F-Mental retardation, Cherry red spot in the macula with Progressive deterioration and death by 3–4 years.

 

Option D: Biotin deficiency includes dermatitis, atrophic glossitis, hyperesthesia, muscle pain, anorexia and hallucinations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The clinical manifestations of carnitine deficiency, including muscle weakness, elevated serum triacylglycerols with LCFAs, hypoglycemia, and lipid accumulation in muscle cells, which reflect the impaired transport of fatty acids into mitochondria for β-oxidation.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e:p 224,231.

choices.text: NADPH and cytochrome P-450 play a role
Involves methyl group at omega end

questions.text: Identify an incorrect statement about omega-oxidation of fatty acids:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Takes place in mitochondria

 

Option A:

 

  • It is a minor pathway taking place in microsomes (Endoplasmic reticulum), with the help of hydroxylase enzymes such as NADPH and cytochrome P-450.
  • The CH3 group is converted to CH2OH and oxidized with the help of NAD+ to a COOH group to produce dicarboxylic acids.
  • ω-oxidation becomes important when β-oxidation is defective and dicarboxylic acids (6C and 8C acids) are excreted in urine resulting in dicarboxylic aciduria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Produce dicarboxylic acids: True, omega-oxidation can result in the production of dicarboxylic acids when the omega carbon of fatty acids is oxidized.

 

Option C: NADPH and cytochrome P-450 play a role: True, omega-oxidation involves the cytochrome P-450 enzyme system, which utilizes NADPH as a cofactor.

 

Option D: Involves methyl group at omega end: True, omega-oxidation involves the oxidation of the methyl group at the omega (last carbon) end of fatty acids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omega-oxidation of fatty acids takes place primarily in the endoplasmic reticulum of cells, not in mitochondria. This pathway serves as an alternative to the β-oxidation of fatty acids, which occurs in mitochondria and peroxisomes.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 205

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presents to the clinic with progressive difficulty in night vision and a recent history of unsteady gait. He reports no significant medical history except for a strict vegetarian diet for many years. Physical examination reveals mild hepatomegaly and decreased ankle reflexes. Laboratory tests show elevated plasma levels of a specific fatty acid. The patient’s condition is suspected to be due to a metabolic disorder affecting fatty acid catabolism:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accumulation of phytanic acid

 

Option A:

 

  • Alpha oxidation is removal of 1C at a time from COOH end  and its takes place in peroxisomes
  • Eg: Phytanic acid (require prior α-oxidation to proceed to ß-oxidation).
  • So, defective or lack of alpha oxidation of phytanic acid leads to its accumulation.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Formation of dicarboxylic acid: Dicarboxylic acids accumulate as a result of ω-oxidation, which typically occurs when β-oxidation is impaired, not α-oxidation.

 

Option C: Formation of propionyl CoA: Propionyl CoA is a product of the β-oxidation of odd-chain fatty acids, not related to α-oxidation defects.

 

Option D: Formation of acetyl CoA: Acetyl CoA is a product of β-oxidation of fatty acids. Lack of α-oxidation does not directly lead to the formation of acetyl CoA.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lack of α-oxidation of fatty acids leads to the accumulation of phytanic acid, a branched-chain fatty acid derived mainly from dietary sources, particularly ruminant fats. Humans lack the enzymes to introduce a double bond in phytanic acid, making α-oxidation necessary for its catabolism. Deficiencies in this pathway, such as in Refsum disease, lead to the accumulation of phytanic acid, which is toxic to cells and can cause symptoms like night blindness, ataxia, and peripheral neuropathy.

 

Ref: Harper 30/ed ,pg 231

choices.text: Different enzymes are found in different site

questions.text: What is this difference in the production of byproducts between beta-oxidation in peroxisomes and that in mitochondria?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) H2O2

 

Option A:

 

Beta-oxidation in peroxisomes differs from mitochondrial beta-oxidation in that it produces hydrogen peroxide (H2O2) as a byproduct. Peroxisomal oxidation involves enzymes that transfer electrons directly to oxygen, forming H2O2. This byproduct is then broken down by catalase, which is abundant in peroxisomes.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Acetyl CoA: Both peroxisomal and mitochondrial beta-oxidation generate acetyl CoA, so this is not a distinguishing feature.

 

Option C: Different enzymes are found in different sites: While it's true that different enzymes catalyze the steps of beta-oxidation in peroxisomes and mitochondria, this option does not refer to a unique byproduct of the reaction.

 

Option D: NADH is required: NADH is a product of mitochondrial beta-oxidation where it is later used in the electron transport chain to generate ATP. Peroxisomal oxidation does not contribute directly to the electron transport chain and therefore the role of NADH in peroxisomal beta-oxidation is not a key distinguishing feature in the context of byproduct production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A modified beta-oxidation pathway takes place in peroxisomes for fatty Acids > C20, C22 (VLCFs)
  • Oxidation in the Peroxisomes → produces Acetyl CoA and H2O2 (instead of FADH2)
  • No ATP is generated.
  • Further oxidation of Acetyl CoA and Octanoyl CoA takes place in the mitochondria.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e page 226

questions.text: In a pediatric clinic, a physician evaluates a 7-month-old male infant presented by his mother with concerns about hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and delayed developmental milestones. Suspecting Zellweger syndrome, a peroxisomal disorder, the physician considers the metabolic abnormalities associated with this condition. Which type of fatty acids is known to accumulate in patients with Zellweger syndrome?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Very long chain fatty acids                                   

 

Option D:

 

  • Zellweger syndrome is also known as Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome which is due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA).
  • Due to mutations in peroxins genes , entry of enzymes into the peroxisomes are denied causing insufficient oxidation of VLCFA leading to its accumulation in CNS causing neurological impairment and death in childhood.
  • It usually presents at birth with profound neurologic impairment and the victims often dying within a year.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: They do not require carnitine for transport across the inner mitochondrial membrane and so are easily oxidized.

 

Option B: Long chain fatty acid accumulation is due to deficiency of long chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase resulting in Nonketotic hypoglycaemia with low carnitine and increased acyl carnitine in plasma.

 

Option C: MCAD accumulation occurs due to deficiency of medium chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase results in acidosis, hyperammonemia, hypoglycaemia and fatty liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome is a peroxisomal disorder characterized by the absence or malfunction of peroxisomes in the cells. One of the key functions of peroxisomes is the β-oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFAs). In Zellweger syndrome, the inability to metabolize VLCFAs leads to their accumulation in tissues and blood, contributing to the clinical manifestations of the disorder.

 

Ref: Harper 30/e: p 241,614

questions.text: A 62-year-old man from Africa with a history of diabetes presents with severe vomiting, epigastric pain, and confusion. He has been using local herbal remedies to manage his blood sugar for the last 8 months and is concerned about possible overconsumption. On examination, he is comatose, dehydrated, and shows signs of tachycardia and tachypnea. Laboratory tests reveal hypoglycemia at 53 mg/dl and a significant electrolyte imbalance. His urine is positive for a high amount of dicarboxylic acid?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Jamaican Vomiting Sickness

 

Option A:

 

  • Ackee fruit that grows in Jamaica and West Africa contain a toxin called Hypoglycin, which is an inhibitor of fatty acyl CoA dehydrogenase.       
  • It causes severe Hypoglycemia if ingested as it inhibits beta oxidation of fatty acids.
  • Characterized by sudden onset of vomiting 2–6 hrs after ingestion, followed by convulsion, coma and death. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Defective oxidation of VLCFA → accumulation of VLCFA in CNS → causes neurological impairment and death in childhood.

 

 Option C:  Carnitine deficiency I  is reported in preterm infants with impaired fatty acid oxidation → more glucose is utilized → hypoglycemia.

 

Option D: Characterized by propionic acidemia, ketoacidosis, and mental abnormalities.

 

Educational objective:

 

Jamaican Vomiting Sickness, which is caused by the ingestion of unripe ackee fruit containing hypoglycin A, a toxin that inhibits fatty acid oxidation. The resulting buildup of dicarboxylic acids in the urine and hypoglycemia due to impaired gluconeogenesis are indicative of this diagnosis.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 219

questions.text:
A 4-day-old male infant, previously healthy, is brought to the emergency department by his mother due to sudden onset of dyspnea followed by loss of consciousness. The infant was born via normal vaginal delivery and had been well until this episode. Tragically, within an hour of arrival, the infant passed away.

 

 

Laboratory investigations revealed the following critical findings:

 

  • Blood sugar: 25 mg/dL, indicating profound hypoglycemia.
  • Elevated levels of medium-chain acylcarnitines.
  • Significant presence of dicarboxylic acids in the urine.

 

Based on the clinical presentation and laboratory findings, which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MCAD Deficiency

 

Option D:

 

MCAD deficiency is a disorder of fatty acid oxidation that prevents the body from converting certain fats into energy, particularly during fasting. This can lead to episodes of low blood sugar (hypoglycemia), weakness, and lethargy. The critical findings in this case—profound hypoglycemia, elevated levels of medium-chain acylcarnitines, and the presence of dicarboxylic acids in the urine—are hallmark indicators of MCAD deficiency. These substances accumulate due to the inability to break down medium-chain fatty acids, leading to the clinical presentation observed in this infant.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Propionic Acidemia - Characterized by the accumulation of propionic acid, this condition typically presents with a metabolic acidosis rather than the specific metabolic derangements seen in this case.

 

Option B: LCACDH Deficiency - This condition affects the metabolism of long-chain fatty acids. The laboratory findings in this infant, however, are indicative of a disorder involving medium-chain fatty acids.

 

Option C: Glutaric Aciduria - This metabolic disorder leads to the accumulation of glutaric acid and typically presents with macrocephaly and neurological signs, which were not reported in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MCAD deficiency - Key diagnostic markers include hypoglycemia, elevated medium-chain acylcarnitines, and dicarboxylic aciduria.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 204.

choices.text: A and R both are right but R is not the correct explanation of A
A is wrong but R is a right statement
A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A
A and R both are wrong

questions.text:
Assertion (A): Hypoglycaemia is common in preterm neonates.

 

Reasoning (R): Carnitine deficiency is seen in preterm infants, who have impaired fatty acid oxidation causing more glucose utilization.
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A as well as R are right and R is a correct explanation of A

 

Option C:

 

Hypoglycemia is indeed common in preterm neonates (Assertion A), partly because of their immature hepatic glycogen stores and the higher brain-to-body mass ratio leading to a rapid glucose consumption. Carnitine deficiency (Reasoning R) is also more frequent in preterm infants due to inadequate stores and less maternal transfer, which leads to impaired fatty acid oxidation, a process that normally helps to conserve glucose. Thus, with compromised fatty acid oxidation, more glucose is utilized, contributing to the risk of hypoglycemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carnitine deficiency is noted in preterm infants, in whom impaired fatty acid oxidation are seen. So more glucose is utilized, resulting in recurrent episodes of hypoglycaemia

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 202

questions.text: Based on the diagram provided, which enzyme is not involved in shuttling fatty acids into the mitochondrial matrix for -oxidation?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Acyl Co-A dehydrogenase

 

Explanation:

 

The diagram shows the carnitine shuttle system, which is responsible for transporting long-chain fatty acids from the cytosol into the mitochondrial matrix, where -oxidation occurs.

 

Option B. Acyl Co-A Dehydrogenase

  • Location: Mitochondrial matrix
  • Function: Catalyzes the first step of -oxidation, dehydrogenating Acyl-CoA to form a trans double bond between the and carbons.
  • Involved in shuttle?  No it acts after the fatty acid has already entered the matrix.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase I (CPT I)

  • Location: Outer mitochondrial membrane
  • Function: Converts Acyl-CoA to Acyl-carnitine by transferring the fatty acid to carnitine.
  • Involved in shuttle? Yes

 

Option C. Carnitine Palmitoyl Transferase II (CPT II)

  • Location: Inner mitochondrial membrane (matrix side)
  • Function: Converts Acyl-carnitine back to Acyl-CoA and carnitine, allowing the fatty acid to enter -oxidation.
  • Involved in shuttle? Yes

 

Option D. Carnitine Acylcarnitine Translocase

  • Location: Inner mitochondrial membrane
  • Function: Transports Acyl-carnitine into the mitochondrial matrix while moving free carnitine back to the cytosol in a counter-transport manner.
  • Involved in shuttle? Yes

 

 

Role of carnitine in the transport of long-chain fatty acids through the inner mitochondrial membrane.


Long-chain acyl-CoA formed by acyl-CoA synthetase enters the intermembrane space. For transport across the inner membrane, acyl groups must be transferred from CoA to carnitine by carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I. The acylcarnitine formed is then carried into the matrix by a translocase enzyme in exchange for a free carnitine and acyl-CoA is reformed by carnitine palmitoyltransferase-II.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Understand the carnitine shuttle system, which is essential for the mitochondrial import of long-chain fatty acids. Key enzymes involved include CPT I, CPT II, and the translocase. Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase is not involved in transportit functions after the fatty acid enters the matrix, initiating -oxidation.

 

Ref: Vasudevan 9/ ed: p151, Harper 30/e: p 224

questions.text:
A 3-year-old girl child brought by her parents with complaints of difficulty in swallowing food, impaired vision at night and hearing impairment for the past 5 months seems to be worsening. O/E:

 

 

 

  • EYES: Bilateral nystagmus
  • FEET: 4th phalange was short in both feet
  • SKIN: dry
  • Electroretinogram: Retinal pigmentation in both fundi.
  • Lab reports: elevated VLCFA and phytanic acid. 

 

What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Infantile Refsum’s disease

 

Option A:

 

The constellation of symptoms such as difficulty swallowing, vision and hearing impairment, specific skeletal abnormalities, dry skin, and distinctive retinal pigmentation, coupled with lab findings of elevated VLCFAs and phytanic acid, points to Infantile Refsum’s disease.

 

This is a peroxisomal disorder characterized by impaired peroxisomal biogenesis and function, leading to the accumulation of phytanic acid and VLCFAs. The clinical manifestations are less severe and present later than in Zellweger syndrome, and the disease typically allows for a longer lifespan.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: Zellweger syndrome: Defective oxidation of VLCFA → accumulation of VLCFA in CNS → causes neurological impairment and death in childhood.

 

Option C: Carnitine deficiency is reported in preterm infants with impaired fatty acid oxidation → more glucose is utilized → hypoglycemia.

 

Option D: Propionyl CoA carboxylase deficiency: characterized by propionic acidemia, ketoacidosis, and mental abnormalities.

 

Educational objective:

 

Difficulty swallowing, night blindness, hearing loss, bilateral nystagmus, brachydactyly, dry skin, retinal pigmentation, and elevated VLCFAs and phytanic acid is diagnosed with Infantile Refsum’s disease, a peroxisomal disorder.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 205

choices.text: 2-Enoyl-CoA hydratase

questions.text: A 26-year-old male long-distance runner presents to his primary care physician with complaints of muscle cramps and fatigue during exercise. He follows a strict low-carbohydrate, high-fat diet and is concerned about his energy levels. Intrigued by the metabolic processes that provide energy during prolonged exercise, he asks about the step in fatty acid oxidation that requires an input of energy. The physician, recognizing this as an important aspect of fatty acid metabolism that could impact the patient’s symptoms, decides to review the biochemical pathway:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acyl-CoA synthetase

 

Option B:

 

  • The first step of fatty acid oxidation requires activation of the fatty acid to an acyl-CoA. This reaction is catalyzed by the enzyme acyl-CoA synthetase and requires ATP which hydrolyses to AMP ~ two high energy phosphates.

 

 

  • In subsequent reactions, two carbons are removed at a time from the carboxyl end to form acetyl-CoA.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The fatty acyl CoA is dehydrogenated to a transenoyl CoA by the enzyme Acyl-CoA dehydrogenase with FAD accepting the hydrogen atoms.  FADH2 when oxidised in electron transport chain will produce 1.5 ATP molecules

 

Option C: Enoyl CoA hydratase catalyzes the step which forms a beta-hydroxy fatty acyl CoA. The L isomer alone is formed during the hydration of the trans-double bond.

 

Option D: The beta-hydroxy fatty acyl CoA is again oxidized to form beta-keto fatty acyl CoA producing a NADH. which further gets oxidized in electron transport chain generating 2.5 ATPs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acyl-CoA synthetase is the enzyme responsible for catalyzing the initial step in fatty acid oxidation where a fatty acid is activated to form acyl-CoA. This reaction requires the hydrolysis of ATP to AMP and pyrophosphate (PPi), making it the only step in fatty acid oxidation that requires an input of energy.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 203

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of congestive heart failure is undergoing a cardiac rehabilitation program. His cardiologist explains the importance of fatty acid metabolism in cardiac muscle for energy production. She details how fatty acids are transported into the mitochondria for β-oxidation, a process especially vital in cardiac tissue, which primarily uses fatty acid oxidation to meet its energy needs. Given the heart's reliance on fatty acids for energy, the cardiologist emphasizes one particular molecule's role in transporting fatty acids across the inner mitochondrial membrane:
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carnitine

 

Option B:

 

  • Fatty acids are activated in the cytoplasm; but beta-oxidation takes place in mitochondria. So, transport of fatty acids across the mitochondrial membrane is essential.
  • The LCFA CoA cannot pass through the inner mitochondrial membrane and requires a transporter, carnitine for transfer of fatty acids (see fig.).

 

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Acyl carrier protein:  Forms a part of fatty acid synthase complex

 

 © LCAT: Lecithin-cholesterol acyl transferase. Involved in HDL metabolism. Apo Al of HDL activates LCAT.

 

Option  D: CETP: The cholesterol ester from HDL is transferred to VLDL, IDL and LDL by a Cholesterol Ester Transfer Protein.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carnitine is crucial for the transport of long-chain fatty acids across the inner mitochondrial membrane in cardiac muscle. It forms a complex with fatty acids to facilitate their translocation into the mitochondria, where β-oxidation occurs to generate ATP for energy.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 202

choices.text: Increased hydrolysis of fat from adipocytes
Decreased synthesis of fatty acids
Impaired beta oxidation of fatty acids

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of chronic alcohol abuse presents to the emergency department with severe abdominal pain. An ultrasound of the abdomen reveals fatty liver. The emergency medicine physician begins to explain to the medical students present that chronic alcohol consumption can lead to hepatic steatosis and outlines the pathophysiological mechanisms behind this condition:
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Impaired beta oxidation of fatty acids.

 

Option D:

 

In alcoholic liver disease, the metabolism of alcohol significantly increases the NADH/NAD+ ratio in hepatocytes, which in turn impairs the beta oxidation of fatty acids. This occurs because the excess NADH inhibits the citric acid cycle, leading to an accumulation of acetyl-CoA and fatty acids within the liver. This impaired fatty acid oxidation, along with increased lipogenesis and decreased VLDL secretion, contributes to the development of fatty liver, or hepatic steatosis, in chronic alcoholics.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Increased hydrolysis of fat from adipocytes: While alcohol can increase lipolysis, the key issue in alcoholic fatty liver disease is the impairment of fatty acid oxidation, rather than an increase in the hydrolysis of fat from adipocytes.

 

Option B: Decreased synthesis of fatty acids: Alcohol consumption typically leads to an increase, not a decrease, in the synthesis of fatty acids in the liver.

 

Option C: Decreased [NADH]/[NAD+] ratio: Alcohol metabolism actually increases the [NADH]/[NAD+] ratio, which is one factor contributing to impaired fatty acid oxidation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Increased level of acetyl CoA causes increased fatty acid synthesis.
  • Impaired beta oxidation of fatty acids leads to increased TAG in the liver resulting in fatty liver and steatosis.

 

Ref: Lippincott 7/e: p317.

choices.text: Decreased ability to convert acetyl coenzyme A to glucose
Increased conversion of acetyl coenzyme A to acetoacetate
Increased production of ATP and nicotinamide adenine dinucleotide

questions.text: A pediatrician is evaluating a 7-month-old boy who was admitted with a seizure, gastrointestinal symptoms, and decreased appetite. Laboratory tests show severe hypoglycemia, normal blood carnitine levels, absence of ketones in the urine, and the presence of various dicarboxylic acids. These findings suggest a diagnosis of medium-chain acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase (MCAD) deficiency. Considering the biochemistry of MCAD deficiency, what is the underlying cause of fasting hypoglycemia in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Decreased acetyl CoA production

 

Option B:

 

MCAD deficiency impairs the body's ability to break down medium-chain fatty acids due to a lack of functional MCAD enzyme. This impedes the production of acetyl CoA from these fatty acids during fasting, when the body normally relies on fat oxidation for energy. Acetyl CoA is crucial for maintaining blood glucose levels via gluconeogenesis during periods without food. In MCAD deficiency, the reduced availability of acetyl CoA limits gluconeogenesis, leading to fasting hypoglycemia

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A: Decreased ability to convert acetyl coenzyme A to glucose: Acetyl CoA cannot be converted to glucose in humans due to the irreversibility of the pyruvate dehydrogenase reaction, which is not specific to MCAD deficiency.

 

Option C: Increased conversion of acetyl coenzyme A to acetoacetate: MCAD deficiency would actually lead to a decreased production of ketone bodies like acetoacetate because there is less acetyl CoA available from fatty acid oxidation.

 

Option D: Increased production of ATP and NAD: MCAD deficiency would result in decreased production of ATP and NADH from medium-chain fatty acid oxidation because the fatty acids are not being properly metabolized.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MCAD deficiency leads to decreased acetyl CoA production from medium-chain fatty acids, which impairs gluconeogenesis and energy production during fasting, resulting in hypoglycemia. The disease also leads to an accumulation of fatty acid metabolites, such as dicarboxylic acids, in the blood and urine.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p204.

questions.text: A neonate in the NICU presents with seizures, poor muscle tone, feeding difficulties, distinct facial features, bilateral cataracts, and ultrasound findings of renal cysts. Blood work indicates elevated very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs), reduced levels of plasmalogen, and increased levels of cholestenoic acid. Based on these clinical findings, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Zellweger syndrome

 

Option A:

 

  • Zellweger syndrome is due to defective oxidation of very long chain fatty acids (VLCFA).
  • Peroxisomes are empty or peroxisomal enzymes are not transported correctly into peroxisomes → leads to insufficient oxidation of VLCFA → accumulation of VLCFA in CNS → neurological impairment and death in childhood.
  • Zellweger syndrome, adrenoleukodystrophy and infantile Refsum’s disease are together classified as Peroxisomal biogenesis disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Infantile Refsum's Disease:  It is also a peroxisomal disorder → phytanic acid accumulation along with VLCFA & Children do not survive long.

 

Option  C. Refsum's Disease: Due to lack of alpha-hydroxylase → alpha oxidation does not occur → phytanic acid accumulates in the tissues → C/F: severe neurological symptoms, polyneuropathy, retinitis pigmentosa, nerve deafness and cerebellar ataxia.

 

Option D. Organic Acidurias: Disorders of metabolism of fatty acids, branched Chain, aromatic amino acids and citric acid cycle → accumulation of organic acids in body tissues and their excretion in urine → acidosis, vomiting, convulsions and coma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome, a peroxisomal biogenesis disorder, is characterized by the absence of functional peroxisomes, which leads to the accumulation of VLCFAs and defects in plasmalogen synthesis necessary for normal cell membrane function.

 

The clinical presentation, including distinctive facial features, cataracts, and renal cysts, along with the specific biochemical abnormalities, strongly suggests Zellweger syndrome.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p209, 254

questions.text: A 28-year-old biochemistry researcher is analyzing energy yield from various metabolic pathways. He is particularly interested in the total ATP production from the complete oxidation of palmitic acid, a common saturated fatty acid. In his experimental setup, he meticulously accounts for all the steps involved in β-oxidation, the citric acid cycle, and the electron transport chain, ensuring accurate calculations of ATP yield:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 106 ATP  

 

Option A:

 

  • Oxidation of C16 fatty acid palmitate: A total of 8 molecules of acetyl-CoA is formed.
  • Each gives rise to 10 molecules of ATP on oxidation in TCA cycle, making 80 molecules.
  • Two must be subtracted for the initial activation of the fatty acid, yielding a net gain of 106 mol of ATP per mole of palmitate.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The total ATP yield in palmitic acid oxidation is 106 ATP

 

Ref: Harper 30/ed ,pg 225

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant presents to the pediatrician with hypotonia, hepatomegaly, and developmental delays. The mother reports that the baby has had difficulty feeding and exhibits poor responsiveness to stimuli. Physical examination notes a high forehead, hypertelorism, and epicanthic folds. The physician, suspecting a genetic disorder affecting cellular organelles, orders a series of diagnostic tests, including metabolic screening and imaging:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Peroxisomes

 

Option C:

 

  • Here the peroxisomes are empty or peroxisomal enzymes are not transported correctly into peroxisomes
  • Zellweger syndrome, adrenoleukodystrophy and infantile Refsum’s disease are together classified as Peroxisomal biogenesis disorders.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: Mitochondria: Disorders associated -Mitochondrial myopathies, Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease.

 

Option B: Lysosomes: Disorders associated – Inclusion cell (I-cell) disease, sphingolipidoses, Mucopolysaccharidosis.

 

Option D: Nucleus: Autoimmune disorders, DNA repair defects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zellweger syndrome is a rare congenital disorder caused by a defect in peroxisome biogenesis, leading to various clinical symptoms such as hypotonia, hepatomegaly, developmental delays, and distinct craniofacial features.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 209, 254

choices.text: Accumulation of very long chain fatty acid
Accumulation of medium chain fatty acid

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to a pediatric neurologist by his parents, who are concerned about recent changes in his behavior and academic performance. Over the past six months, he has exhibited signs of hyperactivity, vision problems, and hearing loss. His teachers have noted a significant decline in his attention span and comprehension skills. The neurologist, suspecting a genetic disorder affecting the metabolism of fatty acids, orders a comprehensive lipid panel including very long-chain fatty acid (VLCFA) levels:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Accumulation of very long chain fatty acid

 

Option A:

 

Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD) is a genetic disorder characterized by the accumulation of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFAs) in the body due to a defect in the peroxisomal transporter protein that imports VLCFAs into peroxisomes for degradation. This accumulation is especially damaging to the myelin sheath of nerve cells, leading to progressive neurological symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B: Accumulation of medium chain fatty acid: ALD does not typically involve the accumulation of medium-chain fatty acids.

 

Option C: Increased plasmalogen: Plasmalogens are a type of phospholipid; their levels are not directly related to ALD, which is primarily concerned with the metabolism of VLCFAs.

 

Option D: Decreased pipecolic acid: Pipecolic acid is associated with peroxisomal disorders like Zellweger syndrome, not specifically with ALD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deficient oxidation of VLCFA by peroxisomal enzyme systems → VLCFAs are accumulated → myelin sheaths are destroyed → adrenoleukodystrophy.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 205

questions.text: Which of the following metabolic pathways generates the most ATP?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fatty acid oxidation

 

Option B:

 

  • Fatty acid oxidation of palmitate results in a total of 106 ATP.
  • A total of 7 rounds of beta-oxidation yield 28 ATPs.
  • A total of 8 mol of acetyl-CoA is formed. Each gives rise to 10 mol of ATP on oxidation in TCA cycle, making 80 mol.
  • Two must be subtracted for the initial activation of the fatty acid, yielding a net gain of 108-2 = 106 mol of ATP per mole of palmitate.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A: The citric acid cycle produces a net of 10 ATP per turn of the cycle

 

Option C: Glycolysis produces a net of 7 ATP molecules per glucose under aerobic conditions.

 

Option D: The pentose phosphate pathway does not generate any ATP but instead forms NADPH and ribose 5-phosphate

 

Educational objective

 

Fatty acid oxidation, specifically β-oxidation of fatty acids, generates the most AT, because the breakdown of fatty acids yields numerous molecules of acetyl-CoA, NADH, and FADH2, all of which enter the citric acid cycle and electron transport chain to produce ATP. Fatty acids are a dense form of energy storage, and their oxidation releases a significant amount of energy.

 

Ref: DM Vasudevan 9/e: p 204.
